Another reference:

 

AKIYAMA, KYUSAKU, Nakamura Kakudaifu Nobuie Tsuba sh=
u [Collection of Rubbings of Nobuie's Sword Guards Belonging to Kakudaifu N=
akamura], T=C3=B4ky=C3=B4:Nanjinsha, 1926 (First edition)
-- 150 pp. printe=
d on double fold paper. Text in Japanese. 
Rubbings of Nobuie tsuba from th=
e Nakamura collection, many of which were lost or destroyed during WWII. Ak=
iyama, the pre-eminent scholar of tsuba of the early part of the 20th centu=
ry, assembled this collection of rubbings. 

--reprinted with supplemental =
material, T=C3=B4ky=C3=B4:Token Shunju Shinbunsha, 1981.

David Zincavage

oshow magazines that have

ll in Japanese but the 
  images are clear. They covered ( in the magazines=
 ) Nobuiye and Kaneiye.

  Jim Gilbert wrote:

  >Pete=
,
  >I can't think of anything in English better than the Tsuba Geijutsu-Ko=
 by Toigoye and Haynes.  I'm sure that there is further commentary in Joly'=
s translations of Akiyama republished in the NCJSC newsletters some years a=
go, but I don't have them organized or indexed.
  >
  >Nobuie Tsuba by Naka=
mura is as good a picture sources as any, at least for having large numbers=
 of examples to compare.  Each mei is attributed to a type in the text of t=
he oshigata section.  The attribution is usually at or near the end of the =
text (lower left portion).  
  >=E6=94=BE=E3=82=8C=E9=8A=98 hanare-mei, =E5=
=A4=AA=E5=AD=97=E9=8A=98 futoji- mei, =E8=A9=B0=E3=82=8A=E9=8A=98 sumari-me=
i, =E5=B7=A6=E5=82=BE=E9=8A=98 sakei-mei and =E7=94=B2=E8=83=83=E9=8A=98 ka=
tchu-mei are ones I saw frequently when I flipped through the book.  
  >
 =
 >In the past there were something like 8 or more categories of mei in use.=
  Most signatures these days are lumped into futoji-mei and hanare-mei.  Th=
ere's quite a bit of variability among accepted examples in each category t=
hough, so things are still not simple.  Wakayama shows some details about t=
he different signatures in the first volume of his Toso Kodogu Koza.  No do=
ubt there are other comparisons in the various survey books.
  >
  >It's a =
difficult area.
  >
  >Jim
